alfredsnippet.snippet:
From p23 of Extraterrestrial Sands:

"if we were to take all the sand in the Sahara it would bury the Earth to a depth of 20 centimeters (8 inches)"

p17:

"El-Baz, apart from participating in the Apollo Program for NASA, has spent many years studying arid environments, particularly the Great Sahara of North Africa and the Arabian Peninsula."

p18, quoting El-Baz:

"The rounding of grains must have occurred in turbid water as the particulate matter was transported during humid phases in the courses of now dry rivers and streams."

p23:

"El-Baz is basically saying that the majority of sand we see today began life as sandstone in the south-west corner of Egypt's western desert ... Taking the sand area as a whole would require shrinking it by about 90 per cent to make it fit."

p24:

"Did a colossal sandstone 'mountain' once tower over this region? Al-Baz provides little in the way of evidence or information here"
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Extraterrestrial Sands - Part 1
